segments.text: I see the woman at the sink, her face so focused on that plate she's polishing.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: It’s like she’s in her own little world, completely oblivious to the mess around her.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The water is gushing from the sink, and I feel a sense of disbelief that she can’t hear it.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: Her foot is right in the puddle, and still, she carries on as if nothing’s wrong.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I’m struck by the absurdity of it all; she’s so focused on a plate while everything else is falling apart.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I glance over at the boy, climbing on that rickety stool, and my heart sinks.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: What if he falls? The last thing I want to witness is an injury because of ignorance.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: And the girl, she’s standing there, hand lifted, waiting for a cookie; it’s so innocent yet so reckless.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I find it amusing yet concerning how they seem to think they can get away with this.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: The cookies are drawing them in like moths to a flame; they don’t see the danger lurking.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: I wish I could yell out, yet I feel like merely a spectator trapped in a drawing.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: And that garden outside looks so inviting while this kitchen is chaos incarnate.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: Will anyone ever learn from this? I ponder the lesson hidden within this mess.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: It’s a strange blend of warmth and worry that fills this moment, and I don't know which part to focus on.
segments.speaker: PAR

segments.text: This kitchen, likely a place of laughter, now feels like a ticking time bomb.
segments.speaker: PAR
